section.title: Trigonometric Functions

introduction.p: In we defined the six trigonometric function values of an acute angle 0 \lt \alpha \lt 90^\circ. In this section we extend our definition of these functions to any angle \theta. Much of this is summarized in the video below.

section.p: Suppose \theta is any angle drawn in standard position in the xy-plane and suppose (x,y) \neq (0,0) is any point on the terminal ray of \theta. Let r = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} \gt 0 denote the radial distance form the origin (0,0) to the point (x,y). Then (x,y) is a point on the circle x^2+y^2=r^2. This setup is summarized in the figure below. Spend some time reviewing it before proceeding.

definition.title: The Six Trigonometric Functions of an Angle

section.p: We maintain the familar reciprocal identities: \csc(\theta) = \frac{1}{\sin(\theta)}, \quad \sec(\theta) = \frac{1}{\cos(\theta)}, \quad \cot(\theta) = \frac{1}{\tan(\theta)} and ratio identities: \tan(\theta) = \frac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}, \quad \cot(\theta) = \frac{\cos(\theta)}{\sin(\theta)}.

example.title: Finding Trigonometric Function Values
example.p: Suppose the terminal side of an angle \theta in standard position includes the point (-3,2). Let's find the six trigonometric function values of \theta.

section.p:
It's tempting to think we can measure the angle \theta in the previous example given the point (-3,2). But keep in mind there are infinitely many coterminal angles that share that point on its terminal side.
Any of the above angles could be the angle in the example. This does not affect the resulting trigonometric function values: coterminal angles have the same trigonometric function values.

principle.title: Trigonometric Function Values of Coterminal Angles
principle.p: Suppose \alpha and \beta are coterminal angles. Then, all trigonometric function values of \alpha and \beta are equal, when they are defined.

statement.p: The terminal ray of a Quadrant IV angle \theta in standard position is parallel to the line y = -x/2. Find the sine, cosine, and tangent of \theta.

solution.p:
Draw a picture of the line y=-x/2 and the terminal ray in the correct quadrant.
Pick any point on the terminal ray. For instance, if I take x=2, then y=-2/2 = -1 so that (2,-1) is a Quadrant IV point on the terminal ray. Then r = \sqrt{2^2+(-1)^2} = \sqrt{4+1} = \sqrt{5}. We have
&\sin(\theta) = \frac{-1}{\sqrt{5}} = -\frac{\sqrt{5}}{5} &\cos(\theta) = \frac{2}{\sqrt{5}} = \frac{2\sqrt{5}}{5} &\tan(\theta) = \frac{-1}{2} = - \frac{1}{2}.

section.p: Trigonometric function values of quadrantal angles are easy to find, but some may be undefined.

example.title: Finding Trigonometric Function Values of a Quadrantal Angle

statement.p: Find the trigonometric function values of \theta = -5 \pi/2, if defined.

solution.p:
We are given the angle measure and can plot this directly. Recall that \pi/2 is one quarter of a revolution. We should count 5 of these quarters in the clockwise orientation.
Pick any point on the terminal side. For instance (0,-1) will suffice. Then r = 1.
&\sin(\theta) = \frac{-1}{1} = -1 &\cos(\theta) = \frac{0}{1} = 0 &\tan(\theta) = {\color{red}\frac{-1}{0}}, \text{undefined} &\csc(\theta) = \frac{1}{-1} =-1 &\sec(\theta) = {\color{red}\frac{1}{0}}, \text{undefined} &\cot(\theta) = \frac{0}{-1} = 0

section.title: Signs of Trig Functions
section.p: As we vary the quadrant of angle, the coordinates of a point on its terminal ray change sign. As a result, the quadrant of an angle determines the sign of each trigonometric function.

statement.p: Suppose \theta is a Quadrant III angle. Determine which trigonometric function values of \theta are positive and which are negative.

theorem.title: Sign of Trigonometric Functions
theorem.p: Summarizing for all four quadrants, we have the following.

figure.caption: QII: x \lt 0, y \gt 0. Only sine and its reciprocal cosecant are positive.
QI: x \gt 0, y \gt 0. All trig function values are positive.
QIII: x \lt 0, y \lt 0. Only tangent and its reciprocal cotangent are positive.
QIV: x \gt 0, y \lt 0. Only cosine and its reciprocal secant are positive.

statement.p: Suppose \csc(\theta) = -4. What quadrant could \theta be in?

solution.p: Since \csc(\theta) = r/y \lt 0 and r \gt 0, we conclude that y \lt 0. This occurs in Quadrants III and IV.

statement.p: Suppose \tan(\theta) is positive. What quadrant could \theta be in?

solution.p: Since \tan(\theta) = y/x \gt 0, we conclude that x and y have the same sign. This occurs in Quadrants I and Quadrant III.

section.p: While there are six trigonometric functions, their values are all related. In fact, one trigonometric function value and the quadrant is sufficient to determine the rest.

principle.title: Fundamental Principle of Trigonometry
principle.p: If you know one trigonometric function value of a non-quadrantal angle and its quadrant, then the remaining trigonometric function values are completely determined by this information.

example.title: Finding Trigonometric Function Values
example.p: Suppose \cot(\theta) = -5/4 and \theta is a Quadrant IV angle. We should be able to find the remaining trigonometric function values of \theta.

statement.p: Suppose \csc(\theta) = 2.25 and \cos(\theta) \lt 0. Find the sine, cosine, and tangent of \theta.

solution.p: Immediately, \sin(\theta) = \frac{1}{\csc(\theta)} = \frac{1}{2.25} \approx 0.44. Sine (y/r) is positive and cosine (x/r) is negative only in Quadrant II. Since \csc(\theta) = \frac{2.25}{1} = \frac{r}{y} so that we may take r=2.25 and y=1. Then r^2 = x^2 + y^2 \Rightarrow x = \pm \sqrt{(2.25)^2 -1^2} \approx \pm 2.02. Since x\lt 0 in Quadrant II, we must take x \approx - 2.02. Then, \cos(\theta) \approx - \frac{2.02}{2.25} \approx - 0.90 and \tan(\theta) \approx \frac{1}{-2.02} \approx -0.50.

section.title: The Reference Angle
section.p: Associated to every non-quadrantal angle is an acute angle called its reference angle. We will see that the reference angle and the quadrant completely determine its trigonometric function values.

definition.title: The Reference Angle
definition.p: Suppose \theta is a non-quadrantal angle in standard position. The reference angle of \theta, denoted by \reference{\theta}, is the smallest positive angle formed by the terminal ray of \theta and the x-axis.

section.p: Study the above and each figure below to see how the reference angle is determine in each quadrant for 0 \lt \theta \lt 2\pi.

example.title: Using the Reference Angle
example.p:
Suppose \theta = 11\pi/3.
The reference angle is formed by the terminal ray and the positive x-axis. This smallest such positive angle is \reference{\theta} = \pi/3. Drawing and \theta and \reference{\theta} both in standard position highlights why its a useful to consider the reference angle.
If (x,y) is a point on the terminal side of \reference{\theta}, then after adjusting for the quadrant, (x,-y) is a point on the terminal side of \theta. Thus, all the trigonometric function values of \theta and \reference{\theta} are the same or opposite and the sign is determined entirely by the quadrant. To illustrate, we know sine is negative in Quadrant IV. So, \sin(11\pi/3) = - \sin(\reference{\theta}) = - \sin(\pi/3) = - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}, where we obtained the last value by referring to the special triangle . Since cosine is positive in Quadrant IV, \cos(11\pi/3) = + \cos(\reference{\theta}) = \cos(\pi/3) = \frac{1}{2}. Since tangent is negative in Quadrant IV, \tan(11\pi/3) = - \tan(\reference{\theta}) = -\tan(\pi/3) = -\sqrt{3}.

section.p: Thus, the use of the reference angle reduces all computations of trigonometric function values down to that of a positive acute angle.

principle.title: Reference Angle
principle.p: Suppose \theta is a non-quadrantal angle with reference angle \reference{\theta}. Then the trigonometric function values of \theta are the same or the opposite of those for \reference{\theta} with the sign determined by the quadrant. (See .)

statement.p: Use the reference angle together with the special triangles and to find the sine, cosine, and tangent of each angle.

li.p:
\theta is in Quadrant III with reference angle \reference{\theta} = \pi/6.
\sin(7\pi/6) = - \sin(\pi/6) = -1/2 \cos(7\pi/6) = - \cos(\pi/6) = -\sqrt{3}/2 \tan(7\pi/6) = + \tan(\pi/6) = 1/{\sqrt{3}}

\theta is in Quadrant II with reference angle \reference{\theta} = \pi/4.
\sin\left(-\frac{5\pi}{4}\right) = \sin(\pi/4) = \sqrt{2}/2 \cos\left(-\frac{5\pi}{4}\right) = -\cos(\pi/4) = -\sqrt{2}/2 \tan\left(-\frac{5\pi}{4}\right) = - \tan(\pi/4) = -1

\theta = 780^\circ = (60+360+360)^\circ is in Quadrant I with reference angle \reference{\theta} = 60^\circ.
\sin(780^\circ) = \sin(60^\circ) = \sqrt{3}/2 \cos(780^\circ) = \cos(60^\circ) = 1/2 \tan(780^\circ) = \tan(60^\circ) = \sqrt{3}

section.title: Basic Identities
section.p: Let's recap some familar relationships between the trigonometric functions.

theorem.title: Reciprocal and Ratio Identities

proof.p:
We have already proved the first indentity. Starting from here and dividing every term by \cos^2(\theta),
\sin^2(\theta) +\cos^2(\theta) =1 \frac{\sin^2(\theta)}{\cos^2(\theta)} +\frac{\cos^2(\theta)}{\cos^2(\theta)} = \frac{1}{\cos^2(\theta)} \left[\frac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}\right]^2 +1 = \left[\frac{1}{\cos(\theta)}\right]^2
Using the , \tan^2(\theta) +1 = \sec^2(\theta). The third identity is left to you to prove.

example.title: Finding Trigonometric Function Values Using Identities
example.p: Suppose \cos(\theta) = -0.7. Let's find the remaining trigonometric function values of \theta, given that \theta is a Quadrant III angle.

By the Pythagorean Identity, \sin^2(\theta) = 1-\cos^2(\theta) so that \sin(\theta) = \pm \sqrt{1-\cos^2(\theta)}. But sine is negative in Quadrant II, so \sin(\theta) = {\color{red}-}\sqrt{1-\cos^2(\theta)} = \sqrt{1-(0.7)^2} \approx -0.51.

Everything falls into place now using ratio and reciprocal identities:
\tan(\theta) \approx \frac{-0.51}{-0.7} \approx 0.73 \csc(\theta) \approx \frac{1}{-0.51} \approx -1.96 \sec(\theta) = \frac{1}{-0.7} \approx -1.43 \cot(\theta) \approx \frac{-0.7}{-0.51} \approx 1.37

introduction.p: The trigonometric functions sine, cosine, and tangent each play a specific role in the geometry of the unit circle. The key concepts in this section are summarized in the video below.

section.title: The Unit Circle
section.p:
Spend a moment reviewing . Each trigonometric function is a certain ratio of x, y, and r, where (x,y) is a point on the circle of radius r \gt 0 centered at the origin (0,0). In particular, \sin(\theta) = y/r and \cos(\theta) = x/r. Rewritting these as,
y = r\sin(\theta) x = r\cos(\theta)
we see that the sine and cosine determine the coordinates of points on the circle.
Moreover, \tan(\theta) = y/x is the slope of the line formed by the terminal side.

example.title: Find a Point on a Circle
example.statement: Using a calculator, estimate the coordinates of the point (x,y) on the circle of radius 4 determined by the angle 207^\circ in standard position. Then find the slope of the dashed line formed by the terminal side of the angle.

section.p: If we restrict to the unit circle with r=1, we obtain a very direct interpretation of the three trigonometric functions.

theorem.title: Unit Circle Trigonometry
